title: France Charbonneau
text:
France Charbonneau is a Canadian judge sitting on the <a href="Quebec%20Superior%20Court">Quebec Superior Court</a>. She was appointed on 4 October 2004.
On the recommendation of <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Rolland">François Rolland</a>, then Chief Justice of the Court, <a href="Premier%20of%20Quebec">Premier</a> <a href="Jean%20Charest">Jean Charest</a> named Charbonneau to chair an inquiry into <a href="Corruption%20in%20Canada%23Qu%C3%A9bec">corruption</a> in the Quebec construction industry on 9 November 2011. Charbonneau headed the inquiry—now known as the <a href="Charbonneau%20Commission">Charbonneau Commission</a>—from 2011 to 2015. The Commission issued its final report on 24 November 2015.
Before her elevation to the bench, Charbonneau served as a <a href="Crown%20attorney">Crown attorney</a> in Quebec for 26 years, beginning in 1979, and worked at as a <a href="Commission%20des%20services%20juridiques">legal aid lawyer</a>. As a Crown, Charbonneau tried over 80 murder cases, including that of <a href="Maurice%20Boucher">Maurice Boucher</a>, and served as a prosecutor on <a href="Quebec%20Biker%20War%23Operation%20Carcajou">Operation Carcajou</a>.
